messages.content:
EAS Build is experiencing a partial outage.
Reason: Partially degraded service for iOS builds
All information on service status and incidents available at https://status.expo.dev/.

It looks like you haven't initialized the git repository yet.
EAS Build requires you to use a git repository for your project.
✔ Would you like us to run 'git init' in /Users/bilalghalib/Downloads/lexicon-staging-3 for you? … yes
We're going to make an initial commit for your repository.
✔ Commit message: … Initial commit
✔ Generated eas.json
EAS project not configured.
✔ Would you like to automatically create an EAS project for @bilalghalib/bloomcommunity? … yes
✔ Created @bilalghalib/bloomcommunity: https://expo.dev/accounts/bilalghalib/projects/bloomcommunity on Expo
✖ Linking local project to EAS project 88378177-8571-4d68-8e06-9b0126fe6fbe
No config exists
    Error: build command failed.

It seems like there was a partial outage on EAS Build for iOS builds, but the current error message is related to the configuration of your EAS project. 

The message indicates that EAS Build requires a git repository for your project and it looks like you haven't initialized one yet. The prompt is asking if you would like to run 'git init' in your project directory to initialize the repository.

Once you have initialized the git repository, the prompt will create an initial commit and generate an eas.json file for your project. After that, it will ask if you would like to create an EAS project automatically. If you choose yes, it will create an EAS project for your app on Expo and link it to your local project.

However, it looks like there was an error when linking your local project to the EAS project, and it seems like the error is related to a missing config file. Without more information, it's difficult to say what the specific issue is. 

I recommend checking the error message again and seeing if there are any more details about what went wrong. You may also want to check the documentation or reach out to the EAS Build support team for assistance.

Running "yarn install" in directory 'frontend' 
yarn install v1.22.17
[stderr] 
warning package-lock.json found. Your project contains lock files generated by tools other than Yarn. It is advised not to mix package managers in order to avoid resolution inconsistencies caused by unsynchronized lock files. To clear this warning, remove package-lock.json.
[1/4] Resolving packages...
[2/4] Fetching packages...
[stderr] 
error Command failed.
[stderr] 
Exit code: 128
[stderr] 
Command: git
[stderr] 
Arguments: ls-remote --tags --heads ssh://git@github.com/samsaffron/react-native-safari-view.git
[stderr] 
Directory: /Users/expo/workingdir/build/frontend
[stderr] 
Output:
[stderr] 
Host key verification failed.
[stderr] 
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
[stderr] 
[stderr] 
Please make sure you have the correct access rights
[stderr] 
and the repository exists.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/install for documentation about this command.
yarn exited with non-zero code: 128

It looks like there was an error when running "yarn install" in the "frontend" directory. The error message indicates that the command failed with exit code 128 and there was an issue with running the "git ls-remote" command to fetch a package.

The error message specifically mentions that the host key verification failed when trying to fetch a package from a remote Git repository located at ssh://git@github.com/samsaffron/react-native-safari-view.git. This suggests that there may be an issue with the SSH connection to the Git repository.

One possible cause of this error could be that the SSH key used to authenticate the connection to the Git repository is invalid or not authorized to access the repository. You may want to check if the SSH key is set up correctly and authorized to access the repository. 

Another possibility is that there may be an issue with the Git repository itself or with the network connection. You may want to check if the Git repository is available and accessible from the machine running the "yarn install" command. 

Finally, the warning message regarding package-lock.json suggests that there may be inconsistencies in the lock files generated by different package managers. You may want to try removing the "package-lock.json" file as suggested in the warning message and then re-run "yarn install" to see if that resolves the issue.
